section.p: CollabNet provides companies with solutions for Collaborative Software Development (CSD) by combining a Web-based software application with a suite of consulting services.

CollabNet is currently working with several Fortune 500 and industry-leading enterprise companies, including: Barclays Global Investors (BGI), Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein (DrKW), Hewlett-Packard (HP), Oracle, and Sun Microsystems. Brian Behlendorf, co- founder of the Apache Software Foundation, established CollabNet in July 1999.

Subversion http://subversion.tigris.org is a free/open-source revision control system that makes it easier for several programmers to cooperate within a set of files. All the files are stored on a server where each individual programmer checks out a working copy and works with that copy. During the project period these files are updated and synchronised with the repository. The repository is much like an ordinary file server, except that it remembers every change ever made to your files. This allows you to recover older versions of your files, or browse the history of how your files changed.

We intend to create a set of .NET assemblies that wrap the Subversion(svn) client API. Further, we will use this wrapper to create a Visual Studio.NET addin for svn. This will allow source control operations to be performed from within Visual Studio itself. Such integration with the IDE will make svn a viable alternative even for Microsoft-centric development shops, which currently mostly use Sourcesafe.

The addin itself will primarily be written in C# on the Windows/.NET platform, with some C/C++/Managed C++ used for the glue layer against the Subversion client API(which is written in C). The natural development tool to use here is Visual Studio .NET. Other tools that might be used include NUnit, a testing framework for .NET, NAnt, a build system and of course Subversion itself for source control.
